Education Secretary Michael Gove said "profound mistakes" made with the curriculum by Labour led to England plummeting in international league tables. The top-performing education nations all have rigorous curricula which act as a benchmark for achievement and a guide to essential knowledge, he wrote in a commentary published yesterday. "But while we have one of the biggest curricula in the world- at nearly 500 pages- it has failed a generation by not preparing them for the

mention a single country apart from the UK or any continents, rivers, oceans, mountains, or cities. It does, however, mention the European Union and global warming." In addition, the secondary music curriculum fails to mention a single composer, musician, or piece of music. The point is to learn from it." Nicholas Macpherson has previously told parliament that Treasury control over spending improved under the last Michael Government. Stephen Williams , co-chair of the Liberal Democrat parliamentary treasury committee, said: This is evidence from the heart of Whitehall that Labour lost control of public spending and is yet another example that Ed Miliband doesn't know what he is talking about. "The Labour leader is living in a fantasy-land where Labour never did anything wrong. Yet every day more evidence comes to light which shows that Gordon Brown 's spendthrift attitude was out of control and his financial management a shambles. am: Tony Blair 's former political secretary Sally Morgan - or Lady Sally Morgan , as she became in 2001- has been named today as the new chairman of Ofsted. Michael Gove , the education secretary, said she was a hugely taLen McCluskeyted individual whose passion is improving education and that she would ensure Ofsted "focuses on improving our schools so we can match the world's best" .
